question: Question_06_(b)
statement:
\textbf{Full-Solution Problem.} Justify your answers and \textbf{show
all your work}. \textbf{Simplification of numerical answers is
required.}

Evaluate $\displaystyle \int \frac{2x-1}{x^2-2x+5} \ dx$
sols:
Note that this is already in reduced form using partial fraction
decomposition. We see that the numerator is \emph{almost} the derivative
of the denominator. We can modify it to be exactly the derivative by
subtracting 1, then adding 1 to make up for it. Then using a simple
substitution in the first integral and completing the square in the
second,

\begin{align*}
\int \frac{2x-1}{x^2-2x+5} \ dx &= \int \frac{2x-2}{x^2-2x+5} \ dx + \int \frac{1}{x^2-2x+5} \ dx \\
&= \ln|x^2-2x+5| + \int \frac{1}{(x-1)^2+2^2} \ dx \\
&= \ln|x^2-2x+5| + \frac{1}{2}\arctan\left(\frac{x-1}{2}\right) + C \end{align*}
hints: Try completing the square in the denominator, then use a substitution.

(alternate) Is there a simple substitution? If not, can you modify the
integrand so that there is?

What is the derivative of the denominator? How does it compare to the
numerator?
